Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandfather learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story: The phone in my hand felt heavier than usual as I glanced at the clock—just one hour left in my shift, and I was still three sales short of my weekly target. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We need you to hit your numbers this week.” I dialed the next number, rehearsing my pitch, but my thoughts kept drifting to the message I’d received earlier. My daughter had texted, saying my grandson was struggling, that he needed to talk to me. As a grandfather, I was supposed to be there, to listen, to offer comfort and guidance. But as a telemarketer, I was expected to keep calling, to push through, to meet the quota that kept my job secure. My heart ached with worry for my family, but my hands kept moving, dialing, selling. The pressure from both sides squeezed me, and I felt torn—my family needed me, but so did my job. I stared at the phone, caught between the demands of being a good grandfather and a reliable employee, unsure which call to make next.
